1. A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of intermittent headaches and recent onset of mild left-sided weakness. He reports occasional episodes of confusion and difficulty concentrating at work. There is no significant past medical history or family history of neurological disorders. Neurological examination reveals subtle left hemiparesis and slight dysarthria. MRI of the brain demonstrates a well-demarcated, frontal lobe mass with calcifications and mild contrast enhancement. MR spectroscopy indicates elevated choline and decreased N-acetylaspartate, suggestive of a glial tumor. A stereotactic biopsy confirms the diagnosis of an oligodendroglioma, IDH-mutant and 1p/19q co-deleted. The patient is subsequently referred to neuro-oncology for combined chemoradiation therapy planning.
